text: think of your image of a Supreme Court
justice circumspect soft-spoken perhaps
those words don't really apply to Sonia
Sotomayor the first Hispanic member of
the Supreme Court and a hit attraction
who is drawing thousands of devoted fans
to an unusually lively series of book
events across the country when I visited
one of her events in Chicago this week
she seemed more like an expert
politician than a judge sharing
inspirational stories dispensing hugs
her fans had lined up for hours
beforehand to get tickets leaving work
early bringing their kids the same thing
has been happening in City after City
wherever she goes part of the appeal of
her book my beloved world currently at
the top of the bestseller list is that
it's so blunt a tale of real childhood
struggle as the diabetic daughter of an
alcoholic father who did not speak
English and a mother who was always at
work last week in Chicago I asked her
whether she had been inspired by Barack
Obama's memoir Dreams from My Father yes
yes did you know did you talk to the
president at all about memoir writing I
did not I he's a little too busy to get
him nice but I thought his book gave it
to me here's a very powerful book
because he actually attempted the way I
have in libel now let's talk honestly
about difficult subjects with her candor
and her deep connection to fans miss
Adama your is revising the role of the
detached cloistered Supreme Court
justice when Jorge Ramos of Univision
came to her chambers to interview her
about her book she played along when he
ended the interview in a surprising way
she says that for her being a role model
is an even more important contribution
to the country than her jurisprudence
which is why she's been spending time on
a very famous street far from the
Supreme Court
not cut Oh Abby I think you'll make a
great great judge thank you
